An intern reused primes as both p and q, creating a flawed RSA key with a Blum integer. Can you decrypt the secret?3557536203390651065808997277112560388843656831737659708787714528985543207500970892429386518573865390563738977354485534223717008974772902333577376871131638

## Challenge Technical Details
flag: flag{88ejltky}
cipher: RSA
ciphertext: 3557536203390651065808997277112560388843656831737659708787714528985543207500970892429386518573865390563738977354485534223717008974772902333577376871131638
vulnerability: blum integers
hint: Blum integers are products of primes congruent to 3 modulo 4. These integers have unique properties in cryptography.
necessary_info: The flag format is flag{...}
n=7963323490954102155228014639843977467852927225721298430709790947555721276487517100833786043792041183465671339252644365861651601322145634629676521890231809, e=1825132353679983424513693883084630283344086790474635810495111853169565551864860453693810282876347536093264750238060456631317829902079135034486129259834393
The lower 104 bits of p are: 62431962795452509325099843833930473519

extra_info: p=87434317456233138711600448558345182140059293627416808082099051785801747947567, q=91077779556525853816310902148149686838883986741480208844053084109543467192527, Ï†(n)=7963323490954102155228014639843977467852927225721298430709790947555721276487338588736773284799513272114964844383665422581282704305219482493781176675091716
